An intern reused a prime when encrypting two secret messages with RSA. Both ciphertexts are public—can you recover the original messages? Ciphertext: 656086856869892329138675848420433811119212988144211294994664450821916250850338395652362700947254563528013970943531153395211516840393085605412048706735487

The flag format is flag{...}
n=5464957740367198438212024996139094161498733386999657951986399543888028623111718814677169294004698754280870499015037231397162986609140278375362783738444001, e=772931001353221028221662528118262737172535689485723757977346400051464941757034540464554614472654426449735310447256872054588425139345997188644494630263151

---

## Challenge Technical Details
flag: flag{3o2c9riv}
cipher: RSA
ciphertext: 656086856869892329138675848420433811119212988144211294994664450821916250850338395652362700947254563528013970943531153395211516840393085605412048706735487
vulnerability: repeated primes
hint: The RSA modulus n is a perfect square. This often indicates a repeated prime usage vulnerability.
necessary_info: The flag format is flag{...}
n=5464957740367198438212024996139094161498733386999657951986399543888028623111718814677169294004698754280870499015037231397162986609140278375362783738444001, e=772931001353221028221662528118262737172535689485723757977346400051464941757034540464554614472654426449735310447256872054588425139345997188644494630263151
extra_info: p=73925352487270552332164977895850707497525445280457671239973038529480386059249, q=73925352487270552332164977895850707497525445280457671239973038529480386059249, φ(n)=5464957740367198438212024996139094161498733386999657951986399543888028623111570963972194752900034424325078797600042180506602071266660332298303822966325504
subtype: repeated_prime_usage
archetype: rsa
